issue.title: Mark stack non-executable when compiling with clang or gcc
issue.body:
Fixes #1159

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [No] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [No] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> > > > @dstebila : Changing the new `add_compile_options` to `add_link_options` seems to do the trick.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Yeah but then I get build failures with gcc-11 on macOS that I haven't been able to resolve.
> > 
> > 
> > Wait, maybe not... checking again...
> 
> That seems to have resolved my build failure. I've just pushed with that change, please check again @vt-alt.

This still reports executable stack. Apparently a lot of binaries still not affected by the flags:
```
altair:~/src/liboqs (sisyphus)$ grep -i '\.S' log2 | grep -v noexecstack -c
229
altair:~/src/liboqs (sisyphus)$ grep -c noexecstack log2
16
```
I think `-Wa,--noexecstack` should be added when building `.S` (as this is `as` flag affecting compilation of .S) or `-Wl,-z,noexecstack` should be added when linking [already compiled] `.S.o`.

This patch is tested to work (on GCC11):
```patch
diff --git a/.CMake/compiler_opts.cmake b/.CMake/compiler_opts.cmake
index 9dd5b323..a7ef0756 100644
--- a/.CMake/compiler_opts.cmake
+++ b/.CMake/compiler_opts.cmake
@@ -67,6 +67,7 @@ if(CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID MATCHES "Clang")
     add_compile_options(-Wextra)
     add_compile_options(-Wpedantic)
     add_compile_options(-Wno-unused-command-line-argument)
+    set(CMAKE_ASM_FLAGS "${CMAKE_ASM_FLAGS} -Wa,--noexecstack")

     if(NOT ${OQS_BUILD_ONLY_LIB})
         set(THREADS_PREFER_PTHREAD_FLAG ON)
@@ -117,6 +118,7 @@ elseif(CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID STREQUAL "GNU")
     add_compile_options(-Wformat=2)
     add_compile_options(-Wfloat-equal)
     add_compile_options(-Wwrite-strings)
+    set(CMAKE_ASM_FLAGS "${CMAKE_ASM_FLAGS} -Wa,--noexecstack")

     if(NOT ${OQS_BUILD_ONLY_LIB})
         set(THREADS_PREFER_PTHREAD_FLAG ON)
```
This is just tested to work too too:
```
diff --git a/.CMake/compiler_opts.cmake b/.CMake/compiler_opts.cmake
index 9dd5b323..a66ce44b 100644
--- a/.CMake/compiler_opts.cmake
+++ b/.CMake/compiler_opts.cmake
@@ -67,6 +67,7 @@ if(CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID MATCHES "Clang")
     add_compile_options(-Wextra)
     add_compile_options(-Wpedantic)
     add_compile_options(-Wno-unused-command-line-argument)
+    set(CMAKE_ASM_FLAGS "${CMAKE_ASM_FLAGS} -Wa,--noexecstack")

     if(NOT ${OQS_BUILD_ONLY_LIB})
         set(THREADS_PREFER_PTHREAD_FLAG ON)
@@ -117,6 +118,7 @@ elseif(CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID STREQUAL "GNU")
     add_compile_options(-Wformat=2)
     add_compile_options(-Wfloat-equal)
     add_compile_options(-Wwrite-strings)
+    add_link_options(-Wl,-z,noexecstack)

     if(NOT ${OQS_BUILD_ONLY_LIB})
         set(THREADS_PREFER_PTHREAD_FLAG ON)
```
I am suggested (by @ldv-alt) that you use `-Wa,--noexecstack` in ASM FLAGS as it's better known solution.

issue.title: XCode update
issue.body: Upgrade XCode environment for OSX to evade CCI deprecation notice.

issue.title: Update Picnic to 3.0.8
issue.body:
This PR updates the Picnic copy to version 3.0.7. Additionally, it slightly reduces the diff between our code and the copy in liboqs by providing a code path for calling `OQS_randombytes` in `randomness.c` and by defining `PICNIC_EXPORT` instead of `PICNIC_STATIC`. `PICNIC_STATIC` is intended for the static build for tests and benchmarking and is intended as an internal flag. With these changes future imports of the Picnic code base should be a bit smoother and should only require a check that `oqs_picnic_macros.h` is still included in the correct places.

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.): It doesn't.
* [x] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.): It doesn't.

comment.body: Hmm -- this merge seems to have been premature: AppVeyor fails since the merge. I'm puzzled, though why this failure didn't materialize/show up in the PR CI (?). @sebastinas Would you want to take a look or shall I do (as I added the cygwin support -- where picnic now fails)?

comment.body: @baentsch I cannot reproduce the issue in a local cygwin installation. Neither the KATs for the upstream Picnic code, nor the liboqs tests fail for me. In any case, if you have fixes that are required for Picnic on cygwin, please send them upstream: https://github.com/IAIK/Picnic

issue.title: Add support for powerpc64
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds support for 64-bit POWER on big-endian.
There is already support for one 64-bit big-endian architecture (s390x).
There is also support for ppc64le (64-bit POWER little-endian).
So this PR shouldn't add much overhead.

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> I don't think there are any that provide out-of-the-box. But e.g. OpenSSL crosscompiles for plenty of platforms: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/.github/workflows/cross-compiles.yml
> That said, I think it may be ok if liboqs builds on both ppc64le and s390x.

Indeed, the OpenSSL matrix also only tests s390x and ppc64le -- as does `liboqs` via Travis. If I'm not mistaken, the only BE PPC are IBM i/AIX machines... So, maybe [this link promising i/AIX "in the cloud"](https://help.skytap.com/skytap-on-ibm-cloud-overview.html) might be an option? Tagging @bhess for an opinion as to whether there's a way (& interest) to add IBM i/AIX to the `liboqs` CI.

issue.title: Add support for powerpc64
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds support for 64-bit POWER on big-endian.
There is already support for one 64-bit big-endian architecture (s390x).
There is also support for ppc64le (64-bit POWER little-endian).
So this PR shouldn't add much overhead.

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: Actually, all the POWER CPUs up to Power10 support BE. It's just that the current trend is to move to LE, but it's not like you can't run BE. In fact, I have a dual boot on my POWER9 workstation with both LE and BE.

issue.title: Add support for powerpc64
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds support for 64-bit POWER on big-endian.
There is already support for one 64-bit big-endian architecture (s390x).
There is also support for ppc64le (64-bit POWER little-endian).
So this PR shouldn't add much overhead.

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> Actually, all the POWER CPUs up to Power10 support BE. It's just that the current trend is to move to LE, but it's not like you can't run BE. In fact, I have a dual boot on my POWER9 workstation with both LE and BE.

Good to know. But if we can't do CI for the "generic" ppc64be platform I'd urge caution to adding it as an apparently fully supported platform to `liboqs`. See for example [this discussion](https://github.com/open-mpi/ompi/issues/4349) for what might ensue (say if some "big endian users" expected `liboqs` to work out of the box). 

So what about the suggestion to add a `cmake` warning message stating "this configuration not tested via continuous integration." (see comment above)?

issue.title: Add support for powerpc64
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds support for 64-bit POWER on big-endian.
There is already support for one 64-bit big-endian architecture (s390x).
There is also support for ppc64le (64-bit POWER little-endian).
So this PR shouldn't add much overhead.

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> Indeed, the OpenSSL matrix also only tests s390x and ppc64le -- as does `liboqs` via Travis. If I'm not mistaken, the only BE PPC are IBM i/AIX machines... So, maybe [this link promising i/AIX "in the cloud"](https://help.skytap.com/skytap-on-ibm-cloud-overview.html) might be an option? Tagging @bhess for an opinion as to whether there's a way (& interest) to add IBM i/AIX to the `liboqs` CI.

I believe most Linux distributions moved to a ppc64le target since little endian (switchable) is supported in POWER8 and later. Using qemu might be an option on Linux. AIX is a good point, but I don't think our CIs support an integration.

> So what about the suggestion to add a `cmake` warning message stating "this configuration not tested via continuous integration." (see comment above)?

Adding a warning is a good idea.

issue.title: Mark stack non-executable when compiling with clang or gcc
issue.body:
Fixes #1159

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [No] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [No] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> > The first option caused build failures when compiling with gcc-11 on my Mac, which I wasn't able to solve.
> 
> I am curios what problem it was? Also, is it creates executable stack there too?

Here's the error I get.    I ran `cmake -GNinja -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=gcc-11 ..` and then `ninja`.  What's very confusing to me is that the compilation command says `gcc-11` but then the error message says `clang: error`.

```
[7/2354] Building ASM object src/kem/classic_mceliece/CMakeFiles/cl...eliece_348864f_avx.dir/pqclean_mceliece348864f_avx/syndrome_asm.S.o
FAILED: src/kem/classic_mceliece/CMakeFiles/classic_mceliece_348864f_avx.dir/pqclean_mceliece348864f_avx/syndrome_asm.S.o 
/usr/local/bin/gcc-11  -I/Users/dstebila/Dev/OQS/liboqs/build-gcc/include -I/Users/dstebila/Dev/OQS/liboqs/src/kem/classic_mceliece/pqclean_mceliece348864f_avx -I/Users/dstebila/Dev/OQS/liboqs/src/common/pqclean_shims -Wa,--noexecstack -fPIC -march=native -Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat=2 -Wfloat-equal -Wwrite-strings -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -fdata-sections -ffunction-sections -Wl,-dead_strip -mavx2 -mpopcnt -mbmi -Wno-language-extension-token -MD -MT src/kem/classic_mceliece/CMakeFiles/classic_mceliece_348864f_avx.dir/pqclean_mceliece348864f_avx/syndrome_asm.S.o -MF src/kem/classic_mceliece/CMakeFiles/classic_mceliece_348864f_avx.dir/pqclean_mceliece348864f_avx/syndrome_asm.S.o.d -o src/kem/classic_mceliece/CMakeFiles/classic_mceliece_348864f_avx.dir/pqclean_mceliece348864f_avx/syndrome_asm.S.o -c /Users/dstebila/Dev/OQS/liboqs/src/kem/classic_mceliece/pqclean_mceliece348864f_avx/syndrome_asm.S
clang: error: unsupported option '--noexecstack'
```

comment.body: @baentsch How can I trigger the cygwin tests for this PR?
